1120069759205138432.text:
Later that summer, Facebook told Instagram—which was growing as strong as ever—that it was slashing IG’s hiring budget. The tension between the two platforms had finally boiled over. 

On a Monday morning, Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger quit. 9/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/yqQtn9kn1C

1120069756877336576.text: The tensions didn’t let up. In August, Facebook made changes to Instagram’s simple design—long a point of pride for the platform—and prototyped a location-­tracking service inside the app. This was exactly the kind of privacy intrusion it had resisted. 8/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/qlZgPxiDh3

1120069755480580097.text: Systrom sent a memo to his entire staff explaining Zuckerberg’s decision. He said he disagreed with the move but was committed to the changes. This enraged Facebook, which was terrified the memo would leak. Systrom soon departed on paternity leave. 7/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/Vigr9g05fh

1120069751764439040.text: After the call, Facebook’s stock dropped by nearly 20%. But Zuckerberg didn’t forget about Insta­gram. He asked for a list of ways Facebook supported traffic to Instagram, then pulled away all of those supports. 6/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/HF95H5NN1G

1120069750007033857.text: In July 2018, before an earnings call where FB disclosed its growth was slowing, Zuckerberg sought to put IG in its place. He debated with close allies whether to say IG owed its growth to FB. He ultimately tempered that point with praise. 5/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/m97uagKbQh

1120069746613870592.text: By 2017, it was clear some at Facebook believed Instagram’s growth was cannibalizing its own. That year, data was presented to senior execs that suggested people were sharing less inside Facebook in part because of Instagram. 4/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/WtOA1IPIk1

1120068804095115269.text: Systrom’s glowing press coverage didn’t help. According to someone at Facebook, in 2014 Zuckerberg ordered that no other execs should sit for magazine profiles without his or Sheryl Sandberg’s approval. 3/ https://wired.trib.al/rmWpxY2 pic.twitter.com/ohB2i5IfVa
